awd_abstract_narration:
Legitimacy is critical for the effective performance of authorities in workplace settings. Legitimated authorities have secured support from their superiors and subordinates, who accept them as appropriate in their positions and are likely to comply with their requests. In contrast, authorities who are not legitimated are likely to be challenged, resisted, and scrutinized. This project addresses two questions: 1) How do authorities gain legitimacy? and 2) How can members of groups that have not typically held positions of authority gain legitimacy, necessary to ensure the productive and smooth operations of the organization?  The hypotheses integrate knowledge about how fairness and power affect legitimacy, how trust is involved, and how status characteristics, i.e., personal attributes such as gender, may condition the process.  These are tested in a series of three studies.  Results will allow development of strategies for authorities, especially women, to ensure their legitimacy in the workplace, thereby improving the effectiveness of modern organizations.

Hypotheses drawn from theories of procedural justice, resource-based power, and status processes are tested via two vignette experiments and one survey study, involving adult samples from the U.S. population.  These studies build on a recently completed vignette study, using undergraduates, that manipulated an authority's use of procedural justice and benevolent power to examine their effects on perceptions of legitimacy. The first study replicates the completed vignette study with employed adults, taking into consideration characteristics of their work experience. A second vignette study manipulates the gender of the authority along with her or his behavior to examine what is required to ensure the legitimacy of female authorities. The third study surveys working adults about their own experiences with authorities in their organizations. Cumulative results from these studies will identify potential strategies for authorities, especially women, to ensure their legitimacy in the workplace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How do workplace leaders and authorities gain legitimacy—i.e., approval and support from others? How can members of groups not typically in positions of authority historically (e.g., women and people of color) gain legitimacy? Leader legitimacy is important to ensure workplace cooperation and productivity.

Results from our scenario studies show several patterns. First, leaders gain legitimacy by using fair procedures, like consistently taking workers’ views into account in an unbiased fashion when making decisions concerning the distribution of valued resources for their workers. Second, leaders who provide resources to all their workers that benefit their welfare and help them group professionally (e.g., training opportunities, strategic information, tools to facilitate doing their jobs) are also more likely to be viewed as legitimate than leaders who fail to do so. Using fair procedures and providing resources also increase workers’ trust in their leader, which in turn bolsters leader legitimacy. Third, leaders who have more experience with workplace tasks and culture owing to their longevity in the position (e.g., three years compared to three weeks) are also more likely to be perceived as legitimate than those with less experience.

Fourth, pathways to legitimacy through perceptions of leaders’ competence and warmth depend on the race of the leader. The perceived competence of white male leaders matters for their legitimacy but for Black male leaders, perceptions of warmth enhance their legitimacy. Finally, leader legitimacy comes with emotional benefits. Leader legitimacy evokes positive emotions (e.g., pleased, satisfied, happy) and reduces negative emotions (e.g., frustration, disappointment, annoyance) from workers. The experience of such emotions potentially facilitates greater cooperation and collaboration in the workplace, thus contributing to leader effectiveness and workgroup productivity. We continue to investigate our research questions based on data from a survey involving over 2000 U.S. adults working fulltime, across a variety of organizations.
